newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan loan body says Sueno declared bankrupt.
newsitem.headline: Japan loan body says Sueno declared bankrupt.

text.p: Sueno Kosan, a major borrower from "jusen" mortgage firms, has been declared bankrupt by Osaka District Court, the semigovernmental Housing Loan Administration Corp said on Monday.

Private credit research agency Teikoku Databank Ltd said debts at Sueno Kosan and its two units totalled 970 billion yen, making it the second-biggest bankruptcy in Japan as a group since the World War Two.
In October, non-bank Nichiei Finance Co Ltd went under with total debts of more than one trillion yen, the largest insolvency case in Japan since World War Two, it said.
Teikoku Databank put Sueno Kosan's own debts at about 700 billion yen.
The HLAC said last month it had claims totalling 347 billion yen on Sueno Kosan and the two units. The claims were transferred from the failed jusen firms to the loan collecting body.
